ple:test.ple:intro:
Hi!
You're about to take our Java test! It's not a super long test, but Java's a big langauge so we cover a lot of different topics.
Don't worry; we're not going to make any decisions based on this test alone. It just gives us a way to get an idea how much Java you know so we can make the best decision about where you might fit in our company.
Please take careful note of the grading guidelines. They are available to look at any time. The important thing to remember is that while you want to answer as many questions as you can, if you really don't know, that's fine. Just leave it blank and it won't count against you.

ple:question.ple:text: When comparing two String variables, what will the == operator do?

ple:answers.ple:answer: Compare the strings case-sensitive and return true if they are the same sequence of characters.
Compare the strings case-insensitive and return true if they are the same sequence of characters.
Compare the object references of the strings to see if they are identical.

ple:question.ple:text: Which are valid ways to create a new string Object?
Given a method protected void foo(), which classes will have access to it?

ple:answers.ple:answer: Any class in the project.
Any class in the same package.
Only the class it is contained in.
Only the classes within the defined security specification.
Any subclass of the class it is contained in.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statements are true about the value of a variable, when no explicit assignments have been made?

ple:answers.ple:answer: The value of a variable of type int is undetermined.
The value of a variable of any numeric type is zero.
A variable of type String will denote the empty String ("")
The value of all variables which are references is null.

ple:question.ple:text: In Java's object model, a class can have multiple ______ but only a single direct ______

ple:answers.ple:answer: Interfaces, child
Children, parent
Interfaces, parent
Parents, interface
None of the above.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statements describe guaranteed behavior of the garbage collection and finalization mechanisms?

ple:answers.ple:answer: An object is deleted as soon as there are no more references that denote the object.
The finalize() method will eventually be called on every object.
The finalize() method will never be called more than once on an object.
An object will not be garbage collected as long as it is possible for a thread to access it through a reference.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statement is true about static classes?

ple:answers.ple:answer: Top-level classes can be declared static.
Classes declared as members of top-level classes can be declared static.
Local classes can be declared static.
Anonymous classes can be declared static.
NO classes can be declared static.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statements are true about nested classes?

ple:answers.ple:answer: No static members (except final static fields) can be declared within a non-static member class.
All fields in a nested class must be declared final.
Anonymous classes cannot have constructors.
An instance of nested class can be considered an instanceof the outer class
All nested classes can be declared static.
A Bar is a Baz.
A Foo has a Bar.
A Baz is a Foo.
A Foo is a Baz.
A Baz has a Bar.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statement is true?

ple:answers.ple:answer: All objects have a finalize() method.
If an exception is thrown during the execution of the finalize() method of an eligible object then the exception is ignored and the object is destroyed
Objects can be destroyed by explicitly calling the finalize() method.
The finalize() method can be declared with any accessibility.
The compiler will fail to compile code that defines an overriding finalize() method

ple:question.ple:text: Which statements are true?

ple:answers.ple:answer: If an exception is not caught in a method, the method will terminate and normal execution will resume.
An overriding method must declare that it throws the same exception classes as the method it overrides.
The main() method of a program can declare that it throws checked exceptions.
A method declaring that it throws a certain exception class may throw instances of any subclass of that exception class.
Finally blocks are executed if, and only if, an exception gets thrown while inside the corresponding try block.
The code will fail to compile because main() does not declare that it throws a RuntimeException
The program will fail to compile, since it cannot throw re.
The program will compile without error and will throw a RuntimeException when run.
The program will compile without error and will throw a NullPointerException when run.
THe program will compile without error and will run and terminate without any output.
DONE
IE F
IE RE E
IE F DONE
IE RE F DONE

ple:question.ple:text: Which statements are true about locks?

ple:answers.ple:answer: A thread can hold more than one lock at a time.
Invoking wait() on a Thread object will relinquish all locks held by the thread.
Invoking wait() on an object whose lock is held by the current thread will relinquish the lock.
Invoking notify on an object whose lock is held by the current thread will relinquish the lock.
Multiple threads can hold the same lock at the same time.

ple:question.ple:text: Which of these are NOT plausible reasons why a thread might be alive, but still not be running.

ple:answers.ple:answer: The thread is waiting for some condition as a result of a wait() call.
The execution has reached the end of the run() method.
The thread is waiting to acquire the lock of an object in order to execute a certain method on that object.
The thread does not have the highest priority and is currently not executing.
The thread is sleeping as a result of a call to the sleep() method.

ple:question.ple:text:
Given classes A, B, and C. B extends A. C extends B. All classes implement the instance method
void doIt()
How can the doIt() method in A be called from an instance method in C?

ple:answers.ple:answer: It is not possible.

ple:question.ple:text: Which statement is true?

ple:answers.ple:answer: A super() or this() call must always be provided explicitly as the first statement in the body of a constructor
If both a subclass and its superclass do not have any declared constructors, the implicit default constructor of the subclass will call super() when run.
If neither super() nor this() is declared as the first statement in the body of a constructor, then this() will implicitly be inserted as the first statement.
If super() is the first statement in the body of a constructor, then this() can be declared as the second statement.
Calling super() as the first statement in the body of a constructor of a subclass will always work, since all superclasses have a default constructor.

ple:question.ple:text: When creating a class that associates a set of keys with a set of values, which of these interfaces is most applicable?

ple:answers.ple:answer: Set
SortedSet
Map

ple:question.ple:text: Given two collection objects referenced by col1 and col2, which statements are true?

ple:answers.ple:answer: The operation col1.retainAll( Col2) will not modify the col1 object.
The operation col1.removeAll( col2) will not modify the col2 object.
The operation col1.addAll( col2) will return a new collection object, containing elements from both col1 and col2.
The operation col1.ContainsAll(Col2) will modify the col1 object.

ple:question.ple:text: Which code segment could execute the stored procedure "countRecs()" located in a database server?
You need to store elements in a collection that guarantees that no duplicates are stored. Which one of the following interfaces provide that capability?

ple:answers.ple:answer: None of the above

ple:question.ple:text: What allows the programmer to destroy an object x?

ple:answers.ple:answer: Only the garbage collection system can destroy an object.

ple:question.ple:text: Which of the following are legal method declarations?

ple:answers.ple:answer: protected abstract void m1();
static final void m1(){}
synchronized public final void m1() {}
private native void m1();
return 0;
return (a 16) | b;
Since the method foo() does not catch the exception generated by the method baz() it must declare the RuntimeException in a throws clause.
A try block cannot be followed by both a catch and a finally block.
An empty catch block is not allowed.
A catch block cannot follow a finally block.
A finally block must always follow one or more catch blocks.
The code will fail to compile.
The constructor in A that takes an int as an argument will never be called as a result of constructing an object of class B or C.
Class C defines three constructors.
Objects of class B cannot be constructed.
At most one of the constructors of each class is called as a result of constructing an object of class C.
c = MyClass.this.a;
Execution proceeds normally and produces no output.
An AssertionError with the message "size" is thrown.
An AssertionError with the message "empty" is thrown.
An AssertionError with the message "element" is thrown.
An IndexOutofBoundsException is thrown.
An AssertionError with the message "container" is thrown.
The code will fail to compile since the constructor is trying to access static members.
The code will fail to compile since the constructor is trying to use static field a before it has been initialized.
The code will fail to compile since the constructor is trying to use field b before it has been initialized.
The code will fail to compile since the constructor is trying to use local variable c before it has been initialized.
The code will compile and run without any problems.
